A normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. It is a prestage to Galois extensions. An algebraic field extension \\(K \subset L\\) is called normal if it satisfies the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4: (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.
Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
Does the concept of a/an Normal field extension need to be defined for a definition of a/an Galois group of a Field Extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
To determine whether the concept of a normal field extension is necessary for the definition of a Galois group of a field extension to make sense, we need to analyze the definitions provided.

1. The definition of the Galois group of a field extension is the group of all field automorphisms of L that fix every element of K. This definition inherently requires understanding what field automorphisms are and how they operate within the context of a field extension L/K.

2. The definition of a normal field extension involves the extension being the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field, and it ensures that every K-homomorphism from L to an algebraic closure of L restricts to an automorphism of L. This property is crucial for the field extension to have a well-defined set of automorphisms that fix K, which are exactly the elements of the Galois group.

3. If an extension is not normal, then there might exist K-homomorphisms from L to its algebraic closure that do not restrict to automorphisms of L. This would mean that the set of automorphisms that fix K might not capture all the symmetries of L over K, or worse, might not form a group at all.

4. Therefore, the normality of the field extension ensures that the set of automorphisms that fix K (i.e., the Galois group) is well-defined and behaves consistently as a group. Without the extension being normal, the concept of the Galois group might not be meaningful or might not exhibit the properties expected of a group.

From this analysis, it is clear that the concept of a normal field extension is necessary for the definition of a Galois group of a field extension to make sense.
